intro: Amaracarpus grandifolius var. humilis, commonly known as the dwarf broadleaf amaracarpus, is a low-growing shrub native to the tropical regions of South America. It features aromatic, lanceolate leaves that are typically 5–10 cm in length and have a velvety texture. The plant produces small, clustered white flowers that bloom in the summer months, followed by elliptical, woody fruits. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in shaded, forested environments. Due to its ornamental value and medicinal properties, it is occasionally cultivated in horticultural settings.
